passages.text: Earlier this morning, news broke that Surface Transportation Board (STB) member Robert Primus had been terminated by the White House. Primus, a Biden appointee and the sole no vote on the CPKC merger, responded that we would fight his ouster.

Change at the STB seems likely. Supreme Court has upheld the Administration's rights to remove individuals from independent agencies, at least temporarily. In Trump v. Wilcox (2025), the Supreme Court allowed the Administration to fire officials from the National Labor Relations Board and the Merit Systems Protection Board. That action, issued in an emergency ruling, allowed the terminations to remain in effect while the case was appealed. It effectively, if temporarily, overturned a unanimous ruling by the Court in 1935 known as "Humphrey's Executor" which established the precedent that the Congress could establish independent agencies and protect their leadership from dismissal without cause. The ruling was temporary, but a good indicator of where the Court sits on the issue of firing the heads of independent agencies (with a carve out for the Fed). This makes it a very difficult fight for Primus to win, in our view.

Reasonable to conclude that this move reduces resistance to mergers on the Board; how much it helps depends on who is appointed. A White House spokesman indicated that Primus was removed because he did not align with the President's agenda and that the White House intends to nominate "new, more qualified" members to the STB in short order. Recall that Primus was the sole "no" vote on the CPKC transaction. The Board as now constituted has 2 Republican appointees (Chair Fuchs, Member Schulz) and 1 Democratic appointee (Member Hedlund). We have heard concerns in the market about approval hinging on the \(5^{\text{th}}\) to be named member...it now hinges on the appointment of two new members. Recall that last week Commerce Secretary Lutnick said he would leave it up to the Regulator decide on mergers.

Reasonable to conclude that this could also indicate a quicker evaluation process. Environmental review is a lengthy component of the rail merger evaluation process. Recall that during the first Trump Administration, the then President signed an Executive Order streamlining environmental review for infrastructure projects. More recently, the Administration expedited environmental reviews tied to data center build outs that support AI development. We have to think that the Administration could be open to an accelerated environmental review of this transaction, which could help close a deal faster than the year and a half most investors we speak to expect.

We remain bullish on Outperform- rated UNP and NSC, and believe the likelihood of a successful transaction (i.e., one that isn't decimated by regulatory concessions) is higher than the market expects.
O - Outperform, M - Market-Perform, U - Underperform, NR - Not Rated, CS - Coverage SuspendedSource: Bloomberg, Bernstein estimates and analysis.

On April 1, 2024, Société Générale (SG) and AllianceBernstein, LP. (AB) completed a transaction that created a new joint venture in which their respective cash equities and research businesses operate in a new business combination. Although their respective ownership percentages in the joint venture differ between North America and the rest of the world, the creation, production and publication of research is handled collaboratively on a global basis across the two research brands, "Bernstein" and "Autonomous". Unless specifically noted otherwise, for purposes of these disclosures, references to Bernstein's "affiliates" relate to both SG and AB and their respective affiliates.

We reach our one- year price target of \(\) 149\(by using our NTM + 1 EPS estimate of\) \ \(8.77\) with a multiple of 17.0x. We use a CAD/ USD exchange rate of 0.735 for our \(\) 110\(one - year price target for the U.S. listed equity (CNI). We justify our multiple valuation with a DCF model where the first stage growth in cash flows and marginal returns on invested capital are based on the output of our financial models, which in turn are driven by explicit assumptions regarding volume, yield, unit cost inflation, productivity and capital expenditures. Perpetuity stage cash flows are valued using an estimate of long term growth in nominal terms and an assumed long term return that is based on each individual company's WACC. Our continuing value estimate of Canadian National includes an assumption that the company earns a 1% premium to its existing WACC, reflecting the nature of the company's assets. In cases where fundamentals are expected to drive major change in cash flows beyond a two - year investment horizon, we use multiples appropriate for a rate of growth expected in future earnings one year from now

We reach our one- year price target of \(\) 120\(by using our NTM + 1 EPS estimate of\) \ \(5.74\) with a multiple of 20.9x. We use a CAD/USD exchange rate of 0.73 for our \(\) 88\(one - year price target for the U.S. listed equity (CP). We justify our multiple valuation with a DCF model where the first stage growth in cash flows and marginal returns on invested capital are based on the output of our financial models, which in turn are driven by explicit assumptions regarding volume, yield, unit cost inflation, productivity and capital expenditures. Perpetuity stage cash flows are valued using an estimate of long term growth in nominal terms and an assumed long term return that is based on each individual company's WACC. Our continuing value estimate of Canadian Pacific includes an assumption that the company earns a 1.2% premium to its existing WACC, reflecting the nature of the company's assets. In cases where fundamentals are expected to drive major change in cash flows beyond a two - year investment horizon, we use multiples appropriate for a rate of growth expected in future earnings one year from now.

We reach our one- year price target of \(\) 36\(by using our NTM + 1 EPS estimate of\) \ \(1.92\) with a multiple of 19.0x. We justify our multiple valuation with a DCF model where the first stage growth in cash flows and marginal returns on invested capital are based on the output of our financial models, which in turn are driven by explicit assumptions regarding volume, yield, unit cost inflation, productivity and capital expenditures. Perpetuity stage cash flows are valued using an estimate of long term growth in nominal terms and an assumed long term return that is based on each individual company's WACC. In cases where fundamentals are expected to drive major change in cash flows beyond a two - year investment horizon, we use multiples appropriate for a rate of growth expected in future earnings one year from now.

We reach our one- year price target of \(\) 305\(by using our NTM + 1 EPS estimate of\) \ \(15.26\) with a multiple of 20.0x. We are taking our multiple higher to reflect discounting of possible merger synergies. We justify our multiple valuation with a DCF model where the first stage growth in cash flows and marginal returns on invested capital are based on the output of our financial models, which in turn are driven by explicit assumptions regarding volume, yield, unit cost inflation, productivity and capital expenditures. Perpetuity

stage cash flows are valued using an estimate of long term growth in nominal terms and an assumed long term return that is based on each individual company's WACC. In cases where fundamentals are expected to drive major change in cash flows beyond a two- year investment horizon, we use multiples appropriate for a rate of growth expected in future earnings one year from now.

We reach our one- year price target of \(\) 286\(by using our NTM + 1 EPS estimate of\) \ \(13.97\) with a multiple of 20.5x. We are taking our multiple higher to reflect discounting of possible merger synergies. We justify our multiple valuation with a DCF model where the first stage growth in cash flows and marginal returns on invested capital are based on the output of our financial models, which in turn are driven by explicit assumptions regarding volume, yield, unit cost inflation, productivity and capital expenditures. Perpetuity stage cash flows are valued using an estimate of long term growth in nominal terms and an assumed long term return that is based on each individual company's WACC. In cases where fundamentals are expected to drive major change in cash flows beyond a two- year investment horizon, we use multiples appropriate for a rate of growth expected in future earnings one year from now.

Downside risks to our target price for CNI include: a material slow down in global economic recovery; changes in government regulation or rule making at either Transport Canada or the US Surface Transportation Board; geopolitical disturbances that limit global trade flows; a slowdown in US or Global economic recovery; strikes or work stoppages at the company's largely unionized workforce; continued development of export volumes into and out of the Port of Prince Rupert; risks attendant to the company's common carrier obligations and the transportation of hazardous materials. From a sector perspective, a change in the seaborne market for metallurgical coal exports from the United States could impact other competitors in the US rail industry.

Upside risk includes strong rail correlation- as shares of the rail stocks are highly correlated, positive changes in investor sentiment for any of the publicly traded companies in the group could impact the value of CN shares.

Downside risks to our target price for CP include: sustained lower global oil prices; a material slow down in global economic recovery; changes in government regulation or rule making at either Transport Canada or the US Surface Transportation Board; geopolitical disturbances that limit global trade flows; a slowdown in US or global economic recovery; strikes or work stoppages at the company's largely unionized workforce; risks attendant to the company's common carrier obligations and the transportation of hazardous materials; strong dependence of the company's further operational improvement on a few key executives; material changes in foreign exchange rates (appreciation of Canadian Dollar vs US Dollar). CP shares are also exposed to key man risks, and any change in leadership would negatively impact the market's perception of future earnings growth.

Upside risks includes strong rail correlation- as shares of the rail stocks are highly correlated, positive changes in investor sentiment for any of the publicly traded companies in the group could impact the value of CP shares.

Downside risks to our target price for CSX include: changes in government regulation or rule making at the US Surface Transportation Board; changes in governmental clean air regulations and their impact on the coal markets; a slowdown in US or Global economic recovery; geopolitical disturbances that limit global trade flows; ability to recruit, train and staff employees as volume driven growth requires resourcing; inflation in global steel prices; strikes or work stoppages at the company's largely unionized workforce; risks attendant to the company's common carrier obligations and the transportation of hazardous materials. CSX is also a party to a class action suit involving fuel surcharges, and any settlement or adverse ruling from that case is not currently reflected in our estimates.

Upside risks to our estimates are regulation of onshore drilling negatively impact natural gas production, rate of economic recovery in the US accelerating dramatically, and global export coal prices maintaining current high levels.

Risks to our target price for NSC include: changes in government regulation or rule making at the US Surface Transportation Board; changes in governmental clean air regulations and their impact on the coal markets; a slowdown in US or Global economic recovery; geopolitical disturbances that limit global trade flows; ability to recruit, train and staff employees as volume driven growth

requires resourcing; inflation in global steel prices; strikes or work stoppages at the company's largely unionized workforce; risks attendant to the company's common carrier obligations and the transportation of hazardous materials. NSC is also a party to a class action suit involving fuel surcharges, and any settlement or adverse ruling from that case is not currently reflected in our estimates. NSC could outperform relative to our estimates should regulation of onshore drilling negatively impact natural gas production, the rate of economic recovery in the US accelerates dramatically, or if there is a disruption in the global supply of metallurgical coal. The most likely sources of underperformance relative to our estimates is a major collapse in export coal demand or a fall of in eastern moves of crude oil by rail.

Downside risks to our target price for UNP include: changes in government regulation or rule making at the US Surface Transportation Board; changes in governmental clean air regulations and their impact on the coal markets; a slowdown in US or Global economic recovery; geopolitical disturbances that limit global trade flows; ability to recruit, train and staff employees as volume driven growth requires resourcing; inflation in global steel prices; strikes or work stoppages at the company's largely unionized workforce; risks attendant to the company's common carrier obligations and the transportation of hazardous materials; ability to retain and re- price legacy energy volumes. Further risks include a more complete collapse of crude by rail (either from economics or from regulation), fall off in Ag pricing due to depressed corn prices, competitive or market driven losses in coal, and the failure of the company to use leverage to repurchase shares.

The Bernstein brand rates stocks based on forecasts of relative performance for the next 12 months versus the S&P 500 for stocks listed on the U.S. and Canadian exchanges, versus the Bloomberg Europe Developed Markets Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (EDM) for stocks listed on the European exchanges and emerging markets exchanges outside of the Asia Pacific region, versus the Bloomberg Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index USD (JP) for stocks listed on the Japanese exchanges, and versus the Bloomberg Asia ex- Japan Large and Mid Cap Price Return Index (ASIAX) for stocks listed on the Asian (ex- Japan) exchanges - unless otherwise specified.
The Bernstein brand has three categories of ratings:

- Outperform: Stock will outpace the market index by more than 15 pp- Market-Perform: Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-15 pp- Underperform: Stock will trail the performance of the market index by more than 15 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.

The Autonomous brand rates stocks as indicated below. As our benchmarks we use the Bloomberg Europe 500 Banks And Financial Services Index (BEBANKS) and Bloomberg Europe Dev Mkt Financials Large and Mid Cap Price Ret Index EUR (EDMFI) index for developed European banks and Payments, the Bloomberg Europe 500 Insurance Index (BEINSUR) for European insurers, the S&P 500 and S&P Financials for US banks and Payments coverage, S5LIFE for US Insurance, the S&P Insurance Select Industry (SPSIINS) for US Non- Life Insurers coverage, and the Bloomberg Emerging Markets Financials Large, Mid and Small Cap Price Return Index (EMLSF) for emerging market banks and insurers and Payments. Ratings are stated relative to the sector (not the market).
The Autonomous brand has three categories of ratings:
- Outperform (OP): Stock will outpace the relevant index by more than 10 pp
- Neutral (N): Stock will perform in line with the market index to within +/-10 pp
- Underperform (UP): Stock will trail the performance of the relevant index by more than 10 pp

Coverage Suspended: Coverage of a company under the Bernstein research brand has been suspended. Ratings and price targets are suspended temporarily, are no longer current, and should therefore not be relied upon.

Not Rated: A rating assigned when the stock cannot be accurately valued, or the performance of the company accurately predicted, at the present time. The covering analyst may continue to publish research reports on the company to update investors on events and developments.
Those denoted as 'Feature' (e.g., Feature Outperform FOP, Feature Under Outperform FUP) are our core ideas. Not Covered (NC) denotes companies that are not under coverage.
For both brands, recommendations are based on a 12- month time horizon.
